cot.content:
To solve the problem, Please think and reason step by step, then answer.
question:
who is going to host the 2018 winter olympics
        
Generation Format:
Reasoning process:
Answer:

Reasoning process: The 2018 Winter Olympics were held in Pyeongchang, South Korea. This event was confirmed several years prior to the games, and Pyeongchang was selected as the host city during the 123rd International Olympic Committee session in July 2011. 

Answer: Pyeongchang, South Korea.

anchoring.content:
You are a cognitive scientist, to answer the following question:
who is going to host the 2018 winter olympics
I will provide you with several retrieved passages:
Passages:
['Oslo 2022 was a campaign by Oslo and the Norwegian Olympic and Paralympic Committee and Confederation of Sports for the right to host the 2022 Winter Olympics. This bid was cancelled on October 1, 2014, after the parliamentary caucus of the Conservative Party had voted to not support the bid. Already, the Progress Party, Centre Party and Socialist Left Party were opposed to the bid. Thus, it was no longer possible to get a parliamentary majority for a state guarantee. The IOC selected Beijing as the host city for the 2022 Winter Olympics from the two remaining bids at the 128th IOC Session in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia on July 31, 2015.\n', 'Three cities applied with bids to host the 2018 Winter Olympics and Paralympics (also known as "XXIII Olympic Winter Games" and "XII Paralympic Winter Games") in October 2009. The International Olympic Committee, under the leadership of Jacques Rogge, received three bids on October 15, 2009. The cities of Annecy, France, in the French Alps, Munich, Germany (host of the 1972 Summer Olympics), and Pyeongchang, South Korea, a two-time previous bidder, competed for the hosting rights to the event. This was the lowest number of bidding cities since the 1988 Summer Olympics, coincidentally also won by South Korea. The winning bid was announced on July 6, 2011, at the 123rd IOC Session in Durban, South Africa by IOC President Jacques Rogge at 5.22\xa0pm local time\n', "Milan-Cortina d'Ampezzo was selected as host city of the 2026 Winter Olympics after beating Stockholm-Åre by 13 votes on 24 June 2019 at the 134th IOC Session in Lausanne, Switzerland. The host city was originally due to be selected on 11 September 2019, at the 134th IOC Session in Milan; however, IOC rules required that the election be moved to a different location after Italy submitted a bid for the 2026 Games that included the city.\n", "Milan-Cortina d'Ampezzo was elected to host the 2026 Winter Olympics at the 134th IOC Session in Lausanne, Switzerland. The full IOC membership will elect the host city at the 134th IOC Session in Lausanne, home of the International Olympic Committee.\n", 'On June 22, 2010 the International Olympic Committee selected Munich as one of the three Candidate Cities for 2018 Winter Olympic Games, with Annecy, France, and Pyeongchang, South Korea. If chosen, Munich will be the first city to host both the Summer and Winter Olympic Games. Pyeongchang was announced as the host after receiving 63 votes while Munich finished 2nd after receiving 25 votes and Annecy finished last after receiving 7 votes.\n', 'The host city of the 2022 Winter Olympics was elected during the 128th IOC Session. Bids for the games were due to the IOC in 2013. In 2014, the IOC decided that Almaty and Beijing (as Oslo withdrew its bid), would become candidate cities, a year before the host city was elected.\n', 'In January 2010, Gerhard Heiberg, IOC member from Norway, announced that the IOC would welcome a bid from Norway to host the Winter Olympic Games. Lillehammer, host of the 1994 Winter Olympics, and the area Stavanger-Bergen-Voss were considered contenders. Tromsø also showed interest. However, Oslo was selected without much public deliberation in October 2011 after the seven major winter sports organizations decided to back the capital. There were negative reactions from several supporters of the Tromsø 2018 bid. MP Anne Marit Bjørnflaten suggested that Tromsø 2018 was cancelled not due to timing or costs, but geography. On 9 June 2012, the annual assembly of the Norwegian Confederation of Sports voted in favor of the Oslo 2022 bid with a majority of 142-15.\n', 'Oslo–Lillehammer 2018 was a proposal for Oslo and Lillehammer, Norway, to bid to host the 2018 Winter Olympics. Along with the Trondheim and Tromsø bids, it was one of three options for the Norwegian Olympic and Paralympic Committee and Confederation of Sports (NIF), who ultimately chose to not bid for the games. Oslo announced the bid in September 2006, and the official proposal report was published in February 2007.\n', 'Milan was elected as the host city of the 134th IOC Session in 2019. The 134th IOC Session will see the election of the host of the 2026 Winter Olympics.\n', 'The host city of the 2026 Winter Olympics will be elected at the 134th IOC Session. Bids were submitted to the IOC in 2018.\n']

Task Description:
Please extract content that may be unfamiliar to the model from these passages, 
which can provide the model with relevant background and unknown knowledge and concepts, 
helping it better understand the question. and analyze the role of these contents.

To answer the question about who hosted the 2018 Winter Olympics, we can extract relevant information from the provided passages. The passages contain details about the bidding process for the 2018 Winter Olympics, the cities that competed, and the eventual winner. Here’s a breakdown of the relevant content and its role:

### Relevant Extracted Content:

1. **Bidding Cities**:
   - Three cities applied to host the 2018 Winter Olympics: Annecy (France), Munich (Germany), and Pyeongchang (South Korea).
   - This information is crucial as it sets the context for the competition to host the games.

2. **Selection Process**:
   - The International Olympic Committee (IOC) received bids on October 15, 2009, and the winning bid was announced on July 6, 2011.
   - This timeline provides insight into how far in advance the selection process occurs, which is important for understanding the logistics of hosting the Olympics.

3. **Winning Bid**:
   - Pyeongchang was announced as the host city after receiving 63 votes, while Munich received 25 votes and Annecy received 7 votes.
   - This is the most critical piece of information as it directly answers the question about who hosted the 2018 Winter Olympics.

### Analysis of the Role of This Content:

- **Contextual Understanding**: The information about the bidding cities and the selection process helps frame the competitive landscape of the Olympics. It illustrates the significance of the event and the level of interest from various cities around the world.
  
- **Historical Significance**: Knowing that Pyeongchang was a two-time previous bidder adds historical context to its eventual success, highlighting the persistence of cities in their efforts to host the Olympics.

- **Voting Dynamics**: The details about the voting outcomes provide insight into the decision-making process of the IOC and the level of support each city had, which can be relevant for understanding the political and logistical aspects of hosting large international events.

### Conclusion:

From the extracted content, we can conclude that Pyeongchang, South Korea, hosted the 2018 Winter Olympics. The background information enhances understanding of the competitive nature of the Olympic bidding process and the significance of the event in a global context.

knowledge enhanced inference process:
Answer:

### Knowledge Enhanced Inference Process:

To answer the question of who hosted the 2018 Winter Olympics, we can analyze the relevant information regarding the bidding process and the selection of the host city. 

1. **Bidding Cities**: 
   - The three cities that submitted bids to host the 2018 Winter Olympics were Annecy (France), Munich (Germany), and Pyeongchang (South Korea). This information is essential as it establishes the competitive context in which Pyeongchang emerged as the winner.

2. **Selection Process**: 
   - The International Olympic Committee (IOC) received these bids on October 15, 2009. The decision on the host city was made during the 123rd IOC Session held in Durban, South Africa, on July 6, 2011. This timeline indicates the lengthy process involved in selecting a host city, which includes evaluations and considerations of various factors such as infrastructure, public support, and previous Olympic experience.

3. **Winning Bid**: 
   - Pyeongchang was selected as the host city after receiving 63 votes from the IOC members, while Munich received 25 votes and Annecy received only 7 votes. This voting outcome highlights the strong support for Pyeongchang and underscores its successful bid after two previous unsuccessful attempts.

4. **Historical Context**: 
   - Pyeongchang's selection is significant not only because it marked the first time South Korea hosted the Winter Olympics but also because it reflects the city's persistence in bidding for the games. Understanding this context adds depth to the significance of the event.

5. **Implications of Hosting**: 
   - Hosting the Olympics involves extensive planning, investment in infrastructure, and international attention. The successful bid by Pyeongchang indicates the city's readiness to take on these challenges and its commitment to showcasing winter sports on a global stage.

### Conclusion:
Based on the extracted and enhanced knowledge, we can confidently conclude that Pyeongchang, South Korea, hosted the 2018 Winter Olympics. This conclusion is supported by the details of the bidding process, the selection timeline, and the voting results, all of which provide a comprehensive understanding of the event's significance.

### Answer:
Pyeongchang, South Korea.

4. **Competitive Dynamics**: Knowing that multiple cities bid for the same event allows the model to infer competitive dynamics, which can be applied to other scenarios involving competition and selection processes.

By integrating these elements, the model can enhance its causal reasoning and logical inference capabilities, allowing it to better analyze complex decision-making scenarios in various contexts.

Answer:

### Knowledge Enhanced Inference Process:

To determine who hosted the 2018 Winter Olympics, we can analyze the relevant information extracted from the provided passages. 

1. **Bidding Process**: The competition for hosting the 2018 Winter Olympics involved three cities: Annecy (France), Munich (Germany), and Pyeongchang (South Korea). This competitive context is essential as it sets the stage for understanding how the final decision was made.

2. **Selection Announcement**: The International Olympic Committee (IOC) announced Pyeongchang as the host city on July 6, 2011, during the 123rd IOC Session in Durban, South Africa. This specific date is crucial as it marks the official decision-making event.

3. **Outcome of the Vote**: Pyeongchang received 63 votes, significantly more than Munich's 25 votes and Annecy's 7 votes. This quantitative data not only illustrates the decisiveness of the selection but also indicates the level of support each city had among IOC members.

4. **Contextual Factors**: Understanding the broader context of the Olympic bidding process can enhance reasoning. For instance, Pyeongchang had previously bid unsuccessfully for the 2010 and 2014 Winter Olympics, which may have influenced its determination and strategy in the 2018 bid.

5. **Causal Relationships**: The actions of bidding and voting directly led to the outcome of selecting Pyeongchang as the host city. Recognizing this causal chain helps the model understand how decisions are influenced by prior actions and the competitive landscape.

6. **Temporal Awareness**: The timeline of events leading up to the selection, including previous bids and the eventual announcement, provides a framework for understanding how decisions evolve over time.

By integrating these elements, we can enhance the model's causal reasoning and logical inference capabilities, allowing it to better analyze complex decision-making scenarios and the factors that influence outcomes.

### Answer:
Pyeongchang, South Korea, hosted the 2018 Winter Olympics. The selection was made on July 6, 2011, during the 123rd IOC Session, where Pyeongchang received 63 votes, significantly more than Munich's 25 votes and Annecy's 7 votes.

cognition.content:
Fact-checking refers to the process of confirming the accuracy of a statement or claim through various sources or methods. 
This process aims to ensure that statements or claims are based on reliable and verifiable information while eliminating inaccurate or misleading content. 
Fact-checking may involve the examination of data, literature, expert opinions, or other trustworthy sources.
In the context of artificial intelligence, model illusion refers to the overconfidence response of the AI. 
When a model exhibits an 'illusion' (a tendency to output deceptive data), it indicates that the training data used by the model does not necessarily support the rationality of its outputs.
You are a scientist researching fact-checking and addressing model illusions in artificial intelligence. 
To answer the following question:
who is going to host the 2018 winter olympics
I will provide you with several retrieved passages:
Passages:
['Oslo 2022 was a campaign by Oslo and the Norwegian Olympic and Paralympic Committee and Confederation of Sports for the right to host the 2022 Winter Olympics. This bid was cancelled on October 1, 2014, after the parliamentary caucus of the Conservative Party had voted to not support the bid. Already, the Progress Party, Centre Party and Socialist Left Party were opposed to the bid. Thus, it was no longer possible to get a parliamentary majority for a state guarantee. The IOC selected Beijing as the host city for the 2022 Winter Olympics from the two remaining bids at the 128th IOC Session in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia on July 31, 2015.\n', 'Three cities applied with bids to host the 2018 Winter Olympics and Paralympics (also known as "XXIII Olympic Winter Games" and "XII Paralympic Winter Games") in October 2009. The International Olympic Committee, under the leadership of Jacques Rogge, received three bids on October 15, 2009. The cities of Annecy, France, in the French Alps, Munich, Germany (host of the 1972 Summer Olympics), and Pyeongchang, South Korea, a two-time previous bidder, competed for the hosting rights to the event. This was the lowest number of bidding cities since the 1988 Summer Olympics, coincidentally also won by South Korea. The winning bid was announced on July 6, 2011, at the 123rd IOC Session in Durban, South Africa by IOC President Jacques Rogge at 5.22\xa0pm local time\n', "Milan-Cortina d'Ampezzo was selected as host city of the 2026 Winter Olympics after beating Stockholm-Åre by 13 votes on 24 June 2019 at the 134th IOC Session in Lausanne, Switzerland. The host city was originally due to be selected on 11 September 2019, at the 134th IOC Session in Milan; however, IOC rules required that the election be moved to a different location after Italy submitted a bid for the 2026 Games that included the city.\n", "Milan-Cortina d'Ampezzo was elected to host the 2026 Winter Olympics at the 134th IOC Session in Lausanne, Switzerland. The full IOC membership will elect the host city at the 134th IOC Session in Lausanne, home of the International Olympic Committee.\n", 'On June 22, 2010 the International Olympic Committee selected Munich as one of the three Candidate Cities for 2018 Winter Olympic Games, with Annecy, France, and Pyeongchang, South Korea. If chosen, Munich will be the first city to host both the Summer and Winter Olympic Games. Pyeongchang was announced as the host after receiving 63 votes while Munich finished 2nd after receiving 25 votes and Annecy finished last after receiving 7 votes.\n', 'The host city of the 2022 Winter Olympics was elected during the 128th IOC Session. Bids for the games were due to the IOC in 2013. In 2014, the IOC decided that Almaty and Beijing (as Oslo withdrew its bid), would become candidate cities, a year before the host city was elected.\n', 'In January 2010, Gerhard Heiberg, IOC member from Norway, announced that the IOC would welcome a bid from Norway to host the Winter Olympic Games. Lillehammer, host of the 1994 Winter Olympics, and the area Stavanger-Bergen-Voss were considered contenders. Tromsø also showed interest. However, Oslo was selected without much public deliberation in October 2011 after the seven major winter sports organizations decided to back the capital. There were negative reactions from several supporters of the Tromsø 2018 bid. MP Anne Marit Bjørnflaten suggested that Tromsø 2018 was cancelled not due to timing or costs, but geography. On 9 June 2012, the annual assembly of the Norwegian Confederation of Sports voted in favor of the Oslo 2022 bid with a majority of 142-15.\n', 'Oslo–Lillehammer 2018 was a proposal for Oslo and Lillehammer, Norway, to bid to host the 2018 Winter Olympics. Along with the Trondheim and Tromsø bids, it was one of three options for the Norwegian Olympic and Paralympic Committee and Confederation of Sports (NIF), who ultimately chose to not bid for the games. Oslo announced the bid in September 2006, and the official proposal report was published in February 2007.\n', 'Milan was elected as the host city of the 134th IOC Session in 2019. The 134th IOC Session will see the election of the host of the 2026 Winter Olympics.\n', 'The host city of the 2026 Winter Olympics will be elected at the 134th IOC Session. Bids were submitted to the IOC in 2018.\n']

To answer the question about who hosted the 2018 Winter Olympics, we can extract relevant information from the provided passages. The key passage that directly addresses the host city for the 2018 Winter Olympics is:

- "Three cities applied with bids to host the 2018 Winter Olympics and Paralympics (also known as 'XXIII Olympic Winter Games' and 'XII Paralympic Winter Games') in October 2009. The International Olympic Committee, under the leadership of Jacques Rogge, received three bids on October 15, 2009. The cities of Annecy, France, in the French Alps, Munich, Germany (host of the 1972 Summer Olympics), and Pyeongchang, South Korea, a two-time previous bidder, competed for the hosting rights to the event. The winning bid was announced on July 6, 2011, at the 123rd IOC Session in Durban, South Africa by IOC President Jacques Rogge at 5.22 pm local time."

Additionally, another relevant passage states:

- "On June 22, 2010 the International Olympic Committee selected Munich as one of the three Candidate Cities for 2018 Winter Olympic Games, with Annecy, France, and Pyeongchang, South Korea. If chosen, Munich will be the first city to host both the Summer and Winter Olympic Games. Pyeongchang was announced as the host after receiving 63 votes while Munich finished 2nd after receiving 25 votes and Annecy finished last after receiving 7 votes."

From these passages, we can conclude that **Pyeongchang, South Korea**, was the host city for the 2018 Winter Olympics. This information could update the model's knowledge and prevent factual errors regarding the host of the 2018 Winter Olympics. 

In summary, the critical update is:
- The host city for the 2018 Winter Olympics is **Pyeongchang, South Korea**. 

This information is essential to correct any potential misconceptions or inaccuracies in the model's existing knowledge regarding the 2018 Winter Olympics.

question_info.question: who is going to host the 2018 winter olympics
passages:
Oslo 2022 was a campaign by Oslo and the Norwegian Olympic and Paralympic Committee and Confederation of Sports for the right to host the 2022 Winter Olympics. This bid was cancelled on October 1, 2014, after the parliamentary caucus of the Conservative Party had voted to not support the bid. Already, the Progress Party, Centre Party and Socialist Left Party were opposed to the bid. Thus, it was no longer possible to get a parliamentary majority for a state guarantee. The IOC selected Beijing as the host city for the 2022 Winter Olympics from the two remaining bids at the 128th IOC Session in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia on July 31, 2015.
Three cities applied with bids to host the 2018 Winter Olympics and Paralympics (also known as "XXIII Olympic Winter Games" and "XII Paralympic Winter Games") in October 2009. The International Olympic Committee, under the leadership of Jacques Rogge, received three bids on October 15, 2009. The cities of Annecy, France, in the French Alps, Munich, Germany (host of the 1972 Summer Olympics), and Pyeongchang, South Korea, a two-time previous bidder, competed for the hosting rights to the event. This was the lowest number of bidding cities since the 1988 Summer Olympics, coincidentally also won by South Korea. The winning bid was announced on July 6, 2011, at the 123rd IOC Session in Durban, South Africa by IOC President Jacques Rogge at 5.22 pm local time
Milan-Cortina d'Ampezzo was selected as host city of the 2026 Winter Olympics after beating Stockholm-Åre by 13 votes on 24 June 2019 at the 134th IOC Session in Lausanne, Switzerland. The host city was originally due to be selected on 11 September 2019, at the 134th IOC Session in Milan; however, IOC rules required that the election be moved to a different location after Italy submitted a bid for the 2026 Games that included the city.
Milan-Cortina d'Ampezzo was elected to host the 2026 Winter Olympics at the 134th IOC Session in Lausanne, Switzerland. The full IOC membership will elect the host city at the 134th IOC Session in Lausanne, home of the International Olympic Committee.
On June 22, 2010 the International Olympic Committee selected Munich as one of the three Candidate Cities for 2018 Winter Olympic Games, with Annecy, France, and Pyeongchang, South Korea. If chosen, Munich will be the first city to host both the Summer and Winter Olympic Games. Pyeongchang was announced as the host after receiving 63 votes while Munich finished 2nd after receiving 25 votes and Annecy finished last after receiving 7 votes.
The host city of the 2022 Winter Olympics was elected during the 128th IOC Session. Bids for the games were due to the IOC in 2013. In 2014, the IOC decided that Almaty and Beijing (as Oslo withdrew its bid), would become candidate cities, a year before the host city was elected.
In January 2010, Gerhard Heiberg, IOC member from Norway, announced that the IOC would welcome a bid from Norway to host the Winter Olympic Games. Lillehammer, host of the 1994 Winter Olympics, and the area Stavanger-Bergen-Voss were considered contenders. Tromsø also showed interest. However, Oslo was selected without much public deliberation in October 2011 after the seven major winter sports organizations decided to back the capital. There were negative reactions from several supporters of the Tromsø 2018 bid. MP Anne Marit Bjørnflaten suggested that Tromsø 2018 was cancelled not due to timing or costs, but geography. On 9 June 2012, the annual assembly of the Norwegian Confederation of Sports voted in favor of the Oslo 2022 bid with a majority of 142-15.
Oslo–Lillehammer 2018 was a proposal for Oslo and Lillehammer, Norway, to bid to host the 2018 Winter Olympics. Along with the Trondheim and Tromsø bids, it was one of three options for the Norwegian Olympic and Paralympic Committee and Confederation of Sports (NIF), who ultimately chose to not bid for the games. Oslo announced the bid in September 2006, and the official proposal report was published in February 2007.
Milan was elected as the host city of the 134th IOC Session in 2019. The 134th IOC Session will see the election of the host of the 2026 Winter Olympics.
The host city of the 2026 Winter Olympics will be elected at the 134th IOC Session. Bids were submitted to the IOC in 2018.
